content.text: State Newton's law of gravitation
A satellite is in a circular orbit around a planet. The radius of the orbit is \(R\) and the period of the orbit is \(T\). The planet is a uniform sphere
Use Newton's law of gravitation to show that \(R\) and \(T\) are related by
where \(M\) is the mass of the planet and \(G\) is the gravitational constant
The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere of mass \(5.98 \times 10^{24} \text{kg}\) and radius \(6.37 \times 10^{6} \text{m}\)
A geostationary satellite is in orbit around the Earth
Use the expression in **(b)** to determine the height of the satellite above the Earth's surface
height =   .........  m
Calculate the angular speed of the satellite in this orbit. Give a unit with your answer
angular speed =   .........  unit   .........
Despite having the same orbital period, the orbit of this satellite is not geostationary
Suggest two ways in which the orbit of this satellite could be different from the orbit of the satellite in (c)
Another satellite is in a circular orbit around the Earth with the same orbital radius and period as the satellite in (c)
State what is meant by an ideal gas
State the temperature, in degrees Celsius, of absolute zero
temperature =   .........  Â°C
the number of molecules of the gas in the vessel
number of molecules =   .........
the mass of one molecule of the gas
the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed \(v\) of the molecules of the gas
A sealed vessel contains a mass of \(0.0424 \text{kg}\) of an ideal gas at \(227^{\circ} \text{C}\)
The pressure of the gas is \(1.37 \times 10^{5} \text{Pa}\) and the volume of the gas is \(0.640 \text{m}^{3}\)

content.text: Use the first law of thermodynamics to describe and explain the energy transfers associated with one complete cycle ABCDA
The state of an ideal gas is continuously changed according to the cycle ABCDA shown in Fig. 3.1
Calculate the frequency of the oscillations
frequency =   .........  \(Hz\)
Show that the amplitude of the oscillations is \(3.4 \text{cm}\)

Describe, without calculation, the interchange between the potential energy and the kinetic energy of the oscillations
A small steel sphere is oscillating vertically on the end of a spring, as shown in Fig. 4.1
The velocity \(\nu\) of the sphere varies with displacement \(\mathbf{x}\) from its equilibrium position according to
where \(\nu\) is in \(\mathrm{cm s}^{- 1}\) and \(\mathrm{x}\) is in cm
the initial charge \(Q_{\mathrm{A}}\) on the plates of capacitor A
the initial energy \(E_{\mathrm{A}}\) stored in capacitor A
State, in terms of \(V\) and \(C\), expressions for:
State and explain what happens to the charge that was initially on the plates of capacitor A
Show that the final potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\) across capacitor B is given by
Explain your reasoning
Determine an expression, in terms of \(V\) and \(C\), for the decrease \(\Delta E\) in the total energy that is stored in the capacitors as a result of the change of the position of the switch
The two-way switch S is now moved to position Y
Two capacitors A and B are connected into the circuit shown in Fig. 5.1
Capacitor A has capacitance C and capacitor B has capacitance 3C
The electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the cell is \(V.\)
The two-way switch S is initially at position X, and capacitor B is initially uncharged
Define magnetic flux
Calculate the magnetic flux through the disc. Give a unit with your answer
magnetic flux =   .........  unit
The disc is rotating at a rate of 25 revolutions per second
Calculate the magnitude of the electromotive force (e.m.f.) induced between the axle and the rim of the disc
The axle and the rim are connected into an external circuit that enables the energy of the rotation of the disc to be stored for future use. The direction of rotation is shown in Fig. 6.1
Use Lenz's law of electromagnetic induction to determine whether the current in the disc is from the rim to the axle or from the axle to the rim. Explain your reasoning
A heavy aluminium disc has a radius of \(0.36 \text{m}\). The disc rotates with the wheels of a vehicle and forms part of an electromagnetic braking system on the vehicle

In order to activate the braking system, a uniform magnetic field of flux density \(0.17 \text{T}\) is switched on. This magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of rotation of the disc, as shown in Fig. 6.1
State the name of the type of rectification produced by a bridge rectifier
Complete Fig. 7.1 by drawing the three missing diodes, correctly connected
On Fig. 7.1, draw an arrow to indicate the direction of the current in resistor R
On Fig. 7.3, sketch the variation of \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) with \(t\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 2.0T\)
The power dissipated in the resistor is \(P\)
On Fig. 7.4, sketch the variation of \(P\) with \(t\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 2.0T\)
Suggest, with a reason, how the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) value of \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) compares with the r.m.s. value of \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\)
\(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) has amplitude \(V_{\mathrm{0}}\) and period \(T.\) Fig. 7.2 shows the variation with time \(t\) of \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\)
Four diodes are used in a bridge rectifier circuit to produce rectification of a sinusoidal a.c. input voltage \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\)
Fig. 7.1 shows part of the circuit, but three of the diodes are missing
The p.d. across the load resistor R is the output p.d. \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) of the bridge rectifier
Explain, with reference to photons, why there is a single frequency of electromagnetic radiation that corresponds to each of these transitions
On Fig. 8.2, draw a line that corresponds to the transition of the electron from \(n = 2\) to \(n = 1\). Label this line A
On Fig. 8.2, draw a line that corresponds to the transition of the electron from \(n = 3\) to \(n = 2\). Label this line B
The frequency of radiation represented by line A is \(f_{\mathrm{A}}\)
The frequency of radiation represented by line B is \(f_{\mathrm{B}}\)
The energy of the ground state \((n = 1)\) is \(E_{1}\)
Determine an expression, in terms of \(f_{\mathrm{A}}, f_{\mathrm{B}}, E_{1}\) and the Planck constant \(h\), for the energy \(E_{3}\) of the energy level \(n = 3\)
Fig. 8.1 shows the lowest four energy levels of an electron in an isolated atom

State the name of particle X

Table 9.1 shows the mass defects of three nuclei

where X is a particle that has no mass defect

the surface temperature of the star

All the energy released from the formation of \(^4_2\mathrm{He}\) is radiated away from the star
All the energy that is radiated from the star has been released in the formation of \(^4_2\mathrm{He}\)

wavelength =   .........  m
X-rays for use in medical diagnosis are produced in an X-ray tube. In the X-ray tube, charged particles are accelerated towards a metal target by an applied potential difference (p.d.)
X-rays pass through a medium that has an attenuation coefficient of \(1.4 \text{cm}^{-1}\)

percentage absorbed =   .........  %
